revision.comment: http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox military conflict |image= |caption= |partof=the [[Spanish–American War]] |date=June 30, 1898 |place=near [[Trinidad, Cuba]] |result=Spanish victory |conflict=Battle of Tayacoba |colour_scheme=background:#ffcccc; color:#2222cc |combatant1={{Flagicon|Spain|1785}} [[Spain under the Restoration|Kingdom of Spain]] |combatant2={{Flagicon|USA|1896}} [[United States]]
{{Flagicon|Cuba}} [[Republic of Cuba]] |commander1=unknown |commander2=Lt. Carter P. Johnson[http://www.spanamwar.com/AfroAmericans.htm Anthony L. Powell, "Black Participation in the Spanish-American War."] [[Emilio Núñez|General Emilio Núñez]] |strength1=100 Spanish [[infantry]], [[7.7 cm FK 96|Krupp field guns]] |strength2=30 infantry and 4 officers,
1 [[gunboat]] |casualties1=unknown |casualties2=1 dead,
7 wounded[http://fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%206/New%20York%20NY%20Tribune/New%20York%20NY%20Tribune%201898%20Jul%20Grayscale/New%20York%20NY%20Tribune%201898%20Jul%20Grayscale%20-%200266.pdf "Landing Aid for Cubans: The Little Peoria Covers Herself with Glory," ''The New York Daily Tribune'', Friday July 15, 1898, p. 2.] }} {{Campaignbox Spanish-American War: Cuba}} The '''Battle of Tayacoba''', June 30, 1898, was a disastrous American effort to land supplies and reinforcements to [[Cuba]]n rebels fighting for their [[independence]] in the [[Spanish–American War]]. ==Background== On June 25 the American steamships ''Fanita'' and ''Florida'' accompanied by the gunboat {{USS|Peoria|1898|6}}[https://books.google.com/books/about/The_History_of_the_Tenth_Cavalry_1866_19.html?id=fKg0AQAAMAAJ Edward L. N. Glass, ''The History of the Tenth Cavalry, 1866–1921,'' Acme Printing Company, 1921, p. 32.] left [[Key West]] carrying a cargo of troops, ammunition, supplies and arms (including two [[dynamite gun]]s, 4,000 [[Springfield Model 1888|Springfield rifles]] and 200 [[Swedish Mauser|Mauser rifles]]), to aid Cuban [[Insurgency|insurgents]] under the command of [[Máximo Gómez]]. On board were 650 Cubans under General [[Emilio Núñez]], fifty troopers of the [[10th Cavalry Regiment (United States)#Spanish–American War|Tenth U.S. Cavalry]] under [http://littletroops.wordpress.com/2011/08/04/quite-a-character-%E2%80%93-carter-p-johnson/ First Lieutenant Carter P. Johnson] and Second Lieutenant George P. Ahern,[https://www.google.com/search?tbo=p&tbm=bks&q=isbn:1442201932 Frank N. Schubert, ''Black Valor: Buffalo Soldiers and the Medal of Honor, 1870–1898'', Rowman & Littlefield, 2009; ISBN 1-4422-0193-2.] and twenty-five [[Rough Riders]] under Captain [http://www.myheritage.com/person-2002863_139921972_139921972/winthrop-astor-chanler Winthrop Astor Chanler],[https://books.google.com/books/about/Heroic_deeds_in_our_war_with_Spain.html?id=NVlHAAAAYAAJ Rice, Wallace, editor. ''Heroic Deeds in Our War with Spain: An Episodic History of the Fighting of 1898 on Sea and Shore'', G.M. Hill, 1898.] brother of Captain [[William A. Chanler|William Astor Chanler]]. The first attempt to land took place on June 29 near the port of [[Cienfuegos]], at the mouth of the San Juan River, however as a result of a [[Battle of Cienfuegos|prior assault on May 11]], the position was too heavily defended to effect a landing.Thomas, Lately. ''The Astor Orphans: A Pride of Lions'', W. Morrow, 1971. The American force then sailed about 40 miles east along the south coast of Cuba, to a point near the town of [[Trinidad, Cuba|Trinidad]]. On June 30 a landing party went ashore on a beachhead just west of Tunas de Zaza, near the mouth of the [http://www.geody.com/geospot.php?world=terra&ufi=-1646813&alc=rAt Tallabacoa River] (mispronounced 'Tayacoba' by the Americans).[http://www.latinamericanstudies.org/book/History_Spanish_American_War.pdf Richard H. Titherington, ''A History of the Spanish-American War of 1898'', New York: D. Appleton and Company 1900, p. 149.] ==Battle== Four miles west of the town, at the mouth of the river, stood a large fort built of railroad iron, surrounded by earthworks and defended by about 100 Spanish regulars. The ''Peoria'' fired several shots with her [[QF 3 pounder Hotchkiss|three-pounders]] into the fort but there was no response. Before dropping off [[mule]]s, men, and [[materiel]], a party of 30 Cubans and Americans led by Captain Jose Manuel Núñez (brother of General Núñez) and including Winthrop Chanler and [[William Louis Abbott|Dr. William Louis Abbott]], went ashore to ensure the safety of the landing site, about 500 yards east of the fort.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=W5xVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=SpsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6959%2C411734 "In a Hot Engagement: Captain Nunez was Killed, Winthrop Chanler and Five Others Wounded." ''The Spokesman-Review'', Spokane, WA July 14, 1898, p. 2.][[File:Dennis Bell.jpg|right|thumb|Private [[Dennis Bell (Medal of Honor)|Dennis Bell]] was awarded the Medal of Honor after participating in the rescue of Cuban soldiers on the beach at Tayacoba.]] Rowing onto the beach, the force crept into the jungle but was discovered by Spanish scouts and came under heavy fire.[http://www.spanamwar.com/10thcavhist.htm Carl Ploense III, "A Unit History of the 10th Cavalry Regiment."] Unable to retaliate or even protect themselves, the Americans retreated onto the beach only to find that their boats had been sunk by Spanish cannon fire. Captain Núñez died of a gunshot wound to the head,[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1915&dat=18980715&id=P_QgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jnQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5130,1035069 "Captain Nunez Killed Outright," ''The Day,'' New London, CT, July 15, 1898, p. 1.] Chanler was shot in the elbow,[http://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC18980715.2.9# "EXPEDITION LANDS AFTER A COMBAT American Force Carries Out a Daring Project With the Loss of Only One Life." San Francisco Call, Volume 84, Number 45, 15 July 1898, p. 2] and Abbott was shot through the right shoulder.[http://www.readcentral.com/chapters/James-Otis/The-Boys-of-98/015 James Otis, ''The Boys of 98'', Ch. XIV "Minor Events." Dana Estes, 1898.] Five Cuban soldiers were also wounded. The party took cover in a [[mangrove swamp]] and one of them, a German surgeon named Dr. Maximilian Lund[https://books.google.com/books?id=-RFYAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA562&dq=%22Maximilian+Lund%22+1900&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5xQ3UsLRA5i84AO4xYHQDw&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Maximilian%20Lund%22%201900&f=false "Acting Assistant Surgeons in the Army," in George Frederick Shrady, Thomas Lathrop Stedman, eds. ''Medical Record,'' Volume 57.] W. Wood, 1900; pp. 561–62. swam out to the ''Peoria'' (naked and armed only with a knife to fend off sharks) to report that survivors on the beach were in need of assistance."NUNEZ KILLED; Chanler's Brother Wounded – Filibusters Get Near the Fire Line." ''Minneapolis Journal'', July 15, 1898, p. 8. ==Rescue== The ''Peoria'' continued firing at the Spanish troops, who were hidden behind a grove of coconut palms. On the ''Florida'' Lieutenant Johnson began organizing rescue attempts. The first four were dispersed by heavy enemy fire and forced to retreat, but the fifth, operating under cover of darkness and crewed by four men of the [[Buffalo Soldier|U.S. 10th Cavalry]] under the command of Lieutenant Ahern, successfully located the Cuban survivors. The body of Captain Núñez was left on the beach. Just before sunrise, a second boat manned by Lieutenant Ahern and [[war correspondent]] (later Lieutenant) Grover FlintGrover Flint, [https://books.google.com/books?id=onAUAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Marching with Gomez: A War-Correspondent's Field Note-Book Kept during Four Months with the Cuban Army''], New York: Houghton-Mifflin, 1899. located Chanler and Abbott. Once they were safely aboard, the ''Florida'' promptly left the bay.[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50916FD345911738DDDAC0994DF405B8885F0D3 "FIGHTING FILIBUSTERS; Expedition to Cuba Has Several Brushes with Spaniards. GEN. NUNEZ'S BROTHER KILLED. Winthrop Chanler of New York and Five Cubans Wounded. Guns of the Peoria Do Great Execution Among the Enemy -- Two Shiploads of Supplies for the Insurgents Landed." ''New York Times'', July 14 1898.] ==Aftermath== [[File:USS Helena LOC det.4a13896.jpg|right|thumb|The USS ''Helena'']]On the afternoon of July 2 the ''Peoria'' returned to the mouth of the Tallacaboa River accompanied by the USS ''[[USS Helena (PG-9)|Helena]]'' and shelled the fort for 30 minutes, damaging the fort and the earthworks. The force then proceeded east to Palo Alto where the troops and supplies disembarked on July 3. On June 23, 1899 four of the five rescuers, Sergeant [[William H. Thompkins]],{{find a grave|7414250|William H. Thompkins|work=Medal of Honor Recipient}} Corporal [[George H. Wanton]],{{find a grave|7866816|George Henry Wanton|work=Medal of Honor Recipient}} Trooper [[Dennis Bell (Medal of Honor recipient)|Dennis Bell]],{{find a grave|6127825|Dennis Bell|work=Medal of Honor Recipient}} and Trooper [[Fitz Lee (Medal of Honor recipient)|Fitz Lee]],{{find a grave|12020|Fitz Lee|work=Medal of Honor Recipient}} all of the [[10th Cavalry Regiment|10th US Cavalry]], were awarded [[Medal of Honor|Medals of Honor]] for their heroism. Winthrop Chanler returned to his home in [[Barrytown, New York]] to recover from his injuries. He returned briefly to military service as a Captain in the [[American Expeditionary Forces]] during [[World War I]]. William Louis Abbott recovered from his wound and returned to his previous occupation as an [[ornithologist]].[http://siarchives.si.edu/collections/siris_arc_217275 ''William Louis Abbott Papers,'' Record Unit 7117], Abbott, William Louis (1860–1936) [[Smithsonian Institution Archives]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{coord missing|Cuba}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tayacoba}} [[Category:Conflicts in 1898]] [[Category:Battles of the Spanish–American War]] [[Category:Naval battles of the Spanish–American War]]
